titleInfo.title: Magnetism and Electronic Complexity in Topological Intermetallic Materials

mods:mods.abstract: Topological materials have gained substantial attention due to their nontrivial band structures and their potential technological application. In parallel, there continues to be strong interest in complex magnetism and the question of how it might be combined with protected topologies to produce new phenomena. Thus motivated, this dissertation focuses on materials that harbor both topological phases and magnetic degrees of freedom. In particular, we present results on Mnintercalated Zr2Te2P, where structural characterization such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) reveals that Mn ions can be intercalated between the Zr layers, leading to the chemical formulas Mn0.06Zr0.03Zr2Te2P. We unexpectedly also find that even the parent compound is also self-intercalated with Zr, leading to the chemical formula Zr0.07Zr2Te2P. The impact of Mn intercalation is evident in the appearance of an anisotropic magnetic susceptibility, where Curie-Weiss fitting indicates that the Mn ions are in a divalent state. Magnetic ordering appears at TM ≈ 4 K and is characterized by a broad transition that is likely due to disordered Mn distribution. Heat capacity and electrical transport measurements show metallic behavior, with an enhanced electronic coefficient γMn ≈ 36.6 mJ/mol-K2 compared to the parent compound. These findings demonstrate that Mn substitution introduces magnetic interactions and tunes the electronic state, suggesting a potential route to producing novel behavior in Zr2Te2P and related ternary tetradymites. Next, we report results for TbSbxTe2−x−δ (x = 0 and 0.50), revealing a complex evolution of the structure going from TbTe1.8 to TbSbTe. To understand this behavior, we propose that there is an intrinsic charge imbalance for TbTe1.8, which causes disorder and structural variation away from the ZrSSi aristotype that is adopted by the charge balanced TbSbTe. This structural variation impacts the magnetic behavior, which exhibits evidence for frustration in TbTe1.8, while TbTe1.34Sb0.50 and TbSbTe simpler antiferromagnetic behavior. Taken together, this shows that this series is a reservoir for rich magnetic phenomena, but further work is needed to assess the evolution of the electronic state. It is also clear that challenges relating to antimony variation and disorder remain to be addressed.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Ryan E. Baumbach, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Laura H. Greene, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Susan Latturner, University Representative; Simon Capstick, Committee Member; Hitesh Jaiprakash Changlani, Committee Member.
